text:
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of caution to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in Western Canada for many years can answer all questions. Some of the questions may not apply to your experience; others may have importance only to you. If they do, don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada for 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer diet
( ) Pioneer schools
( ) Pioneer churches
( ) Pioneer recreation and social life
( ) Pioneer farming experiences
( ) Folklore in Saskatchewan
( ) Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaire

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to you or your family; others may prove impossible for you to answer. Don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada for more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark two ones you would be willing to answer:

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer diet
( ) Pioneer schools
( ) Pioneer churches
( ) Pioneer recreation and social life
( ) Folklore in Saskatchewan
( ) Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have corrections also do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: F. EDWARD WILMOT
2. Your address: MAYAMENT, SASKATCHEWAN, SASKATCHEWAN
3. Date: JULY 23, 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): SLough
5. What was your father's name and occupation: BUCKINGHAM, ENGLAND
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): WILLIAM WILMOT, June 1905
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you were a small child; "It was in by tears", etc).
   Answer: 25 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Possibly being taught much by the Indians, learning their ways, seeing how they live, hearing much talk about young Indians uprising, and I thought it was beautiful there.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    My information obtained from Shapley and Canadian government offices in Gordon's Land.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have answers also do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: ERWAKO, WILMOT
2. Your address: MAYMENT, SASKATCHEWAN
3. Date: JULY 22, 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): SLOUGH, BUCKINGHAM, ENGLAND
5. What was your father's name and occupation? WILLIAM, WILMOT, FARMER
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): JUNE, 1905
7. Mention other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you say why I was a child). I was in my teens, etc.
9. What were your reasons for coming West? Possibly being taught much of the business Canada
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Ballad or government information?)

My information obtained from "Saskatchewan" and "Canada"

Government offices in London, England.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They were very surprised when I decided to leave home.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I traveled with my wife, Mrs. William Henry Wilmot.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Steamship from England.

14. What incidents of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Nothing of extraordinary importance. Please note an incident that is memorable about our journey.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Brandon, Manitoba.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Poveshuig, 8th July 1905.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

In Canada, especially Toronto 1916-1919.

In 1931, I took up homestead at what is now known as Junor.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

I was a carpenter in England and a lumberjack in Canada.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They were very surprised by my decision to come here.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   I traveled with my wife and family.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   We used a steamship from England.

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, adventures, etc.)
   Nothing of extraordinary importance. Please note.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Regina, July 8th, 1905

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   In Canada, 1911-1915

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   In Canada, 1911-1915

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How long after you came?
   I worked as a farmer in England and then came to Canada.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, where did they settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

See above question 21

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Went on a trip always in May/June 1906 also at Roadwork & Melville Roads. Western Alberta too.

attended church. Anglican. Mayors who was built in 1909. You could drive your prairie deck for two years during in 1910. Grew and down through the years during Povesh. Communion Hall and other places for which figure thanks to offerings $5.00 for the opportunity to do same. To this summer glory.

Mowbrack mostly in early days & later with snow wagon.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, where did they settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

25. Any other questions?
25. When was the first car used in the community? (Not sure if this year but)

26. If you owned a car before 1934, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

Yes, I came here because my mother promised to go to war in France. You know, I promised to keep my promise, telling my homeland, "Hey, what's going on?" We don't have much money and we can't do our life.
25. When was the first car used in the community? (not any of the year but)

26. If you owned a car before 1934, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your traveling center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to travel there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? Did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My wife Mrs. E.J. Wilmot was leader of the Girl Guides for a year or so before 1930. Wilmot was organized by the Junior Branch about 1928 (PEARL)

37. If you or any of your family or friends were ever forced to have or do something in the district of your residence, please list all such events.

(pearl) as owning the first automobile, combining, etc., etc.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and derivation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in names since the first name was given; date and reason for change; give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Maymont I have always understood was named in honour of a lady, Mrs. May Montgomery, relative to a builder & H.R.

One through Maymont and JUNIOR SASK was named after the Pemmican Co. South west of Pearl Lake. After rail way came through, town near junior river was the Post Office was moved to Black Lake Rail Station and in Pearl known the Railway Station were named junior.

PEARL School named after the first teacher Mr. Pemmican.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My aunt Mrs. E. Wilmot was head of the Girl Scouts for a year or so before 1930. Pearl was organized by the Chamber of Commerce to pay Ray (1938-1943) was organized by the Junior Board School District (PEARL).

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates whenever possible.

Such as owning the first automobile, constructing a building, etc.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, etc.)

Give (1) name and location of person, agency, place-name, (2) origin of name and meaning of the name, (3) date of its adoption, (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Maymont: Name always pronounced as if written in Roman.

Originally named "JUNIOR" Station, named after the prominent land owner JUNIOR BIRCHLAKE. P.O. Office named after the railway line which ran through the town. The town was named after the railway line which ran through the town.

Office was named to PEARL after the PEARL school district was named after the Chamber of Commerce.
Questions regarding historical source material:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of councils, by-laws, minutes? (Describe).

Anything to show us what your town looked like?

Anything to show us what your town looked like?

Would you or the person who owns them either:

(1) Be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) Be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library? (Indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

41. What do you think was the most important change in your community since you first came West?

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:

Written by myself — Edward Wilmot

Maymont, B.C.
Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of letters, old photos, old photographs, written accounts, etc., which may contain historical material?

(1) Be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying. . . . .
(2) Be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library in Regina, or the Archives Office at the University of Saskatchewan.

Please give the names and addresses of other persons who could answer this questionnaire.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person sign and address here:

Written by myself - Edward Wilmot

[Signature]

Please give the names and addresses of other persons who could answer this questionnaire.

Memories of Mr. & Mrs. Edward Wilmot on Leaving England for Canada on June 3rd, 1905 with Ten Month Old Son William Henry Wilmot

We sailed from England, London Docks on the "Allan" Line Steamer Barmanian 31st June Saturday June 3rd 1905.

Called at Havre, France, staying there one day was permitted to go ashore and saw a little charity feeding hour most day and crossed the Atlantic to Quebec and Montreal.

We had a very pleasant voyage except for one stormy day. It was very interesting the large fish (porpoises) believe in great numbers gathered around the ship in great numbers. Then too on reaching Canada the large sealings, quite a few of them were young up the mouth of the St. Lawrence river as lightning storms during the night and getting up in the morning to see the villages with their...
Copy

Memoirs of Mr. & Mrs. Edward Wilmot on Leaving England for Canada on June 3rd, 1905 under Ten Months Old Son William Henry Wilmot.

We sailed from England London Docks on the "Allan" Line Steamer Barmanian Saturday June 3rd, 1905.

Called at Havre, France, staying there one day was permitted to go ashore and saw a little eighty-five year old man named Mr. Smith.

We had a very pleasant voyage except for one stormy day. It was very interesting the large fish (porpoises) following great numbers gathered around the ship in great numbers. From Toronto or Montreal Canada the large schools go up the mouth of the St. Lawrence river as lightning storms during the night and getting up in the morning to see the villages with their...
Blind sheep looking like prisoners doled out fine and
there along the shore looking out Cheshire them closer
on to move back away there Sunday June 17th.

Following Monday we came to Newbury next day
she rammed us stayed over for three or four days
then rushed to continue own journey to Bathford
so we had planned before leaving England

We were informed at Newbury that we could
only get tickets to as far as Humbleton so they
were more than two hours the deal "Had been laid
on our way at Humbleton back we travel a few
miles where until we finally crawled into what
was to be North Bathford somewhat unexpectedly
the final passenger train (of which I am not
quite sure). Our luggage was dumped out on
ground which we had no leave
still we could see were tents mobile charge I
believe there was a log plastered brick dairy on
south side of church
the hotel was a manager (and) the restaurant and
worse than was the same.
Church chapel looking like pictures dotted pine and
trees along the shore, looking at Chautauqua Lake
on Wednesday morning June 19th.

Journeying northward on train for New York next day
we traveled we stayed over night or four days
then wished to continue our journey to Barreford
so we had planned before leaving England

We were informed at Milwaukee that we could
only get tickets to as far as Humboldt so they
were not sure how far the steel "road" went back
on arriving at Humboldt back we traveled afar-
ward North Barreford on what was probably
the first passenger train (of which I am not
quite sure). Our baggage was dumped out on
ground which we had to leave
all we could see were tents mobile change
before there was any pleasant building on
south side of track
the hotel was a house (not) the restaurant and
work-room was the same
We left to go across river to Banffford the following
morning. We packed a new and thrilling experience crossing
the river watching the buggies hung low and the horses
and mules hanging in hitched buggies pulled on top of
each other, then gradually and slowly crossing the
river.

Then we changed the direction to Invermere.
Building that was quite another experience (learned
not much). It was shelter for us (through cloudy)
as was appreciated.

In a day or so we purchased a tent & two life
rafts walls and camp stove which was our only
store and shelter for that winter.

If you work (camping) for a week or so then
we moved back to town Banffford. I remember
well carrying him and poles with camp stove and
what else. Mr. Wilmet carrying Henry and other
things he could manage and hauled up the path
of nature leading to now the city purchasing our first
a little wear of the Post Office and moving him
to town as the buildings were being built fast. If you
work again and be used to the Canadian way of
living was very strange.
We left to go across river to Barnlyford the crossing was quite a narrow and thrilling experience crossing a ferry watching them buggies carry horses and cows and mules living in kitchen buggies piled on top of each other then gradually and slowly crossing the river.

Then we changed the direction to Immigrator Barnlyford that was quite another experience (car in dust not much it was shelter for us through our day) it was appreciated.

In a day or so we purchased a tent & four legs for a foot walls and camp stove which was our only shelter was heater for that winter.

If you work in camp (working) for a week or so then we moved back to town Barnlyford Premium Co well carrying him and poles with camp stove and what else. Mr. Nelson carrying Henry and other Always she could manage and build up the path of course heading to town the city purchasing our last little wear of the Poor Coffin and moving him to town as the buildings were being built fast. If you work again and big used to the Canadian way of building was very strange
The morning it shut you know we walked together I am
amazed when I cross the bridge when travelling
by railway in and out it chapman.
Our and was near a young married couple I'm sure
Percy Knowles will you marry daughter Edmundo from
New Orleans Decatur & Homestead NE Sec 8 J41
3 miles south of Homestead South.
On July 9th I flew on it and a day or so later took
the train to Yulee where I remained for two weeks
on Shackleford on Shackleford walking the beaches for
homestead to see what it was like. Nothing in particular
noting was looking around and was eaten in the
gold rush appearance of the gold like flecks in a man
came along young towards building who chopped
and cut down will Mr. Yurin was his name
an old prospector and was had a very pleasant
conversation about how those stories happened to come
true there he young family I saw a man on
horseback galloping towards me and I found out
his name was Mr. Yurin at the trail at that
time passed through Rio Chico and what happens
would be his barn.
The morning it was pouring we walked together I am convinced when I cross the bridge when travelling my railway in and out of civilization.

Our next was near a young married couple but I have partly thrown in with young daughter Edith Evans from Mr. Houlton's farm at a homestead NE of Sec 2 July 3 miles south of Marymount South.

On July 9th I fell on my knees and a day or so later Cook the train to Yelvington while I remained there was known as Blacktown on Blackwater walking the 6 mile to homestead to see what it was like, nothing in our town.

Mineral was looking our store and interested in what gold tube appeared to be gold like flashes a man came along young towards building who stopped and asked whom with me. Mr. Yurman was his name an old prospector and we had a very pleasant conversation. How these stories happened to come to life there in Garry family I knew a man on horseback galloping towards me and I found out his name was Mr. Yurman the Traveling Chef turns proved to be a shock and what Dampier would be his team.
5 shillings food at Mrs. Brown's
and I had noticed a building being erected
especially someone working on it! So I was journeying
to find out what it was about. Mrs. Brown
gave me a ride in her buggy. (Maymont)
I worked at the Butterfield for a month or two on them
with Mr. Brown. (He was always having horses
in his wagon which he had much trouble buying between Buttefield
and Maymont) and ourselves with the journey on
knock to own homesheads and build our own log
shack hoping to get into before the cold weather came.
On land we were caught still in own Kenton snow.
Storm which was several inches deep, luckily we could
carry wood to fuel which was in a cliff nearby.
The winter was not such a cold one (but cold enough)
so the mud between logs shrunk.

I perhaps would mention here own living was
flour for bacon while beans which we had difficulty
getting them to soften in cooking and rabbits which
we then killed. You, I remember I had gone out
with a rifle and shot a prairie chicken which
was our first Christmas dinner in Canada, and it
was so yummy and warm it lasted us a long time
this day.
5 children, food at hand, house warming,
and I had noticed a building being erected nearby,
especially someone working on roof! But I couldn't
see anyone or turn and found out after it was too late.

So we went to Hotel Boulton for tea and lunch on them
light May 19th. Knowles (as we called him) having been
working at Hotel Boulton for two months or so, was in them
town when he heard much talk about between Saskatchewan
and Montana) and ourselves took the journey on
our own homesteads and built our small log
shack hoping to get into before the cold weather came.

On that day we were caught still in our tent in snow.
Storm which was unusual inches deep. Luckily we could
carry wood for fuel which was in a blizzard.

The winter was mild, such a cold one (but cold enough)
so the small shelter kept us warm.

I remember well a mention here own living was
flown for bacon while Cream which we had difficulty
gathering them to assist in cooking and rabbit rabbits
in a thin rabbit. You, I remember I had gone out
with 22 rifle and shot a prairie chicken which
was our first Christmas dinner in Canada and it
was so yummy and warm we ate our lamb during
the day.
We knew through the summer and autumn in the first
warm days of spring, the river running through the
town, and also a couple of weeks more experience again
when the warm rains came, and looking from above,
the prairie was one white mass of mushrooming
all around us, we had a change of feet.

Remembering too, the what we understood was the
Hudson's Bay Boat, bumping and chugging its way up
towards Bathurst.

During that summer the Brownmores were formed as
we knew them today, of which David Brown was the
year 1955 celebrating the 50th jubilee year.

Later two Provincial elections were held and the
first minister for Red River was the late Hon.

George Langley

Close this with perhaps only one regret that I
would wish to you in these celebrations and
know she would have been able to give us a man
and send accounts of what had happened in the past.

Edward Remot
We lived through the winter and summertime the first
winter days by spring, the river running through the
town, and also a great one until more experience again
when the warm rains came, and looking from shore,
the province was one while mass of mushrooming
all around us, we had a change of heart.

Remembering too, the what we understood was the
Hudson Bay Road, being and chugging its way up
towards Bathurst and.

During that summer the provinces were formed as
we know them today, a million dollar dream in the
year 1955 celebrating the 50th jubilee year.

Further two provincial elections were held and the
first minister for Redding was the late Hon.

George Langley

Close this with perhaps only one regret their Mum
would wish us to join in these celebrations as she
knew she would have been able to give us a man
and much account of what had happened in the past.

Edward Remot
This account of our earlier journeyings was written at the request of my nephew Paul Wallace of Robinhood, Sask., as he had been asked by his school principal to try and obtain any experiences of early settlers to the province.

E. Wilmot
This account of our earlier journeys was written at the request of my nephew Paul Wallace of Robinhood, Sask., as he had been asked by his school principal to try and obtain any experiences of early settlers in the province.

E. Wilmot
Oxford
